What we are suggesting is that a double task con¬
fronts us. One, the task of creating dynamic
listening materials, and two, the problem of
achieving and maintaining attention for the whole
period of exposure, in a setting conducive to learning.
We feel that in developing acceptable program formats
for radio broadcasting, the one variable, reflected
best in a description of age levels, is the concen¬
tration span of the target population. Programs,
therefore, must be specifically designed for each age
grouping: the pre-school - the pre-teen - the teen¬
ager - and the adult population.
We believe that this is a more serious factor in re¬
gard to radio broadcasting because of the total absence
of the visual dimension, and because of the total
direct appeal to the imagination of the listening group.
In transmitting educational materials, certainly, the
probability of the environment intruding into the
learning situation is very high. In other situations,
with television, this becomes negligible as a factor.
